Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

GOP candidate McSally is going all in on her alignment with Trump rhetoric and is ready to vote for the next Supreme Court nominee.  This will help keep some of her votes but I do not see how she can reduce the hefty lead of Dem candidate Kelly in the polls.

SCOTUS fight is a phenomenon that energizes the base of the party opposing the incumbent.  The manner in which this nomination process is being rushed will further excite. Polls in AZ race continue to show D leading by a consistent 6 point margin and early voting is underway in the state.
Mark Kelly has been gaining momentum monthly. By the time of the election he should be in the high 50's low 60's in terms of outcome.
Mark Kelly has out raised his opponent and is popular.

Down-ballot voting will have significant impact in this election year vis a vis R vs D. The D candidate is a popular pick, astronaut with sentimental attachment through his marriage to Gabby Gifford, who was nearly killed by a nut-job. R candidate was picked to fill the seat and has not impressed AZ electorate.

Although Arizona appears red from the outside – think: Barry Goldwater, Sheriff Joe Arpaio, Kelli Ward -- it actually has quite a bit of blue on the inside: * Five of its nine federal House members are Democrats;
* 29 of its 60 state Legislators are Democrats;
* 13 of its 30 state Senate members are Democrats; and
* The currently elected Senator, Kyrsten Sinema, is a Democrat (and openly bisexual, to boot). The Daily Kos ran an interesting article a few weeks ago -- "Together we can destroy Republican trifectas in these two battleground states" – pointing out that, starting in 2016, Democrats have been steadily making inroads into the state’s political infrastructure. Starting with Sheriff Joe Arpaio being voted out of office that year, and picking up steam in 2018 when the GOP lost four seats in the statehouse they had controlled for 50 years. They are now hanging on to the statehouse by a thread, and a handful of strong Democratic candidates stand a decent chance of flipping at least one chamber this year. In the most recent Presidential poll Joe Biden is leading Donald Trump in Arizona by nine points (49% to 40%), even though Trump beat Clinton by five points, and Romney beat Obama by 10 points. Within that context, according to FEC filings: * As of 07/15, Kelly has raised $45,735,788, spent $24,516,845, and has $21,218,943 cash on hand.  
* As of 09/08, McSally has raised $30,019,767, spent $19,965,687, and has $10,977,873 cash on hand Note: McSally's fundraising numbers have not changed substantially from her 07/15 report, when she had raised $30,018,096, spent $19,947,472, and had $10,994,417 cash on hand. The most recent Arizona Senate poll of likely voters (Benenson Strategy Group, 08 Sep) shows: * Kelly: 48%  
* McSally: 45% The weighted averages over the last 16 Arizona Senate polls going back to 16 July (based on 538 rankings) are:   * Kelly: 50.9%  
* McSally: 41.7%   Cook Political Report of 23 July rate this race: Leans blue
Larry Sabato's Crystal Ball of 05 Aug rated this race: Leans blue
Inside Elections with Nathan Gonzales of 10 July rated this race: Tilts blue
Kelly's 17 point lead has shrunk to single digits in just under a month. However the lead has been maintained.

Arizona has traditionally been a "red state."  It has been trending "purple" for a while.  The Democratic candidate is extremely well positioned for the state.  Military background.  Astronaut.  Elected wife shot while in office.  Much of this plays well with the Republican base of AZ.  
Still - overcoming the "red bias" of the state is going to be tough.  That's why I don't have him at a higher percentage chance.

A little less than four months to go, and I think it’s time to go all-in for Kelly. McSally couldn’t beat Sinema in 2018. She’s definitely not positioned to beat Kelly now. He’s ahead of her in the polls, ahead of her in fundraising, and - let’s face it - just a better all-around choice for Arizona. Trump and Ducey’s mishandling of the virus isn’t doing her any favors either. I’ll drop this back from 100% if circumstances change, but at the moment I don’t see a path to a McSally victory.

The rationale behind my decision was based on these potentially important factors: Maricopa County, Suburban voter trends, historical voting Patterns, Incumbent Approval Rating, & Current Polling. I also considered Gun-Right activism and the impacts of Down-Ballot (The impact of presidential approval rating on members from the same party). I removed Gun-Rights ownership and Down-ballot voting from final results because I could not find significant amount of evidence to prove that these would be important factors come November.  Suburban Voters had one of the most striking impacts on the 2018 elections senate elections. This has the potential to continue in the new election especially in one of the most important counties Maricopa. I have not seen evidence to suggest there will be another shift in the suburban voter demographic. This competitive county has historically voted republican but recently switch during the 2018 election. This is likely due to a rapidly changing demographics but there has also been a  link to suburban voting trends. Historical voting patterns definitely support a republican candidate, however the incumbent's approval rating and polling has drop dramatically, 4 months away from the election. Even before the recent civil unrests and COVID-19, polling suggested that the incumbent would loose. On top of that, polling for the president in the national election has also fallen in swing state - Arizona. Based on the historical voting patterns in Arizona I believe that this race will be much closer than the current polling measures might indicate, however, most of the evidence still leads me to conclude that this election will result in a democratic candidate winning in November. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/23/us/politics/arizona-2020-election-democrats-republicans.html
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/arizona/

https://www.latimes.com/politics/story/2020-05-15/biden-focuses-arizona-key-state

Arizona voters are famously contrarian.  Although Arizona tends to be a reddish state, the perception of the Republican Party writ large will suffer sufficiently to put a Democrat in the Senate.  Mark Kelly's experience as an astronaut (heroic), his wife who gains much sympathy from the shooting incident several years ago, and Trump's increasing disapproval ratings afford Kelly and the Democrats the upper hand.

Kelly (D) was originally neck and neck with McSally (R), but around early March Kelly starting taking a lead in the polls, which has only solidified since then. McSally may have precedence after taking over for McCain, but Kelly seems more popular. National policies in reaction to the coronavirus, as well as current Black Lives Matter protests may be helping in pushing  the country towards the democratic side. On the other hand, Arizona is typically a republican state, and the state of the country will not last forever. The tides may very well turn back to the norms over time. How the two candidates continue to react to current events through the election in September, particularly regarding the coronavirus and the handling of the police, may very well be the deciding factor of the race.

Mark Kelly is looking very strong and the Dems generally are at worst a toss-up to win the state. I think some people are ruling out the GOP too far though, this is still a red state for the time being.
Looks like the polls are very consistent over last 2 months with Kelly getting getting over 50% votes

Recent polls gives the democratic candidate Kelly a clear lead over republican McSally.[1] While I see it as likely that Kelly will win, I'm a bit less confident than the crowd. Republican primary isn't done yet which may result in some split among republicans who will afterwards unite behind their candidate, it is in recent decades (although not the last election) a republican state which hasn't seen two democrats occupying the senate seats since 1953 and it also of course a few months until the election so a lot can still change. 1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Arizona

The candidate defending the seat was appointed and had lost in filling Flakes seat. Her opponent has a good name in the state and his wife has been in congress before. He has been working the crowds for over a year. I feel supper solid that he will win if he is alive on election day.

Although Arizona is typically more red-leaning purple, I think the covid crisis is about to really blow up for them.  When they see the republican party treat it like a hoax, and continue having rallies, I think some of these states are about to find themselves a lot more disillusioned.  I think it's going to be just enough to turn blue, at least for this election.
The democrats anti-cop and allowing riots and looting will hurt their chances of re-election.
Both sides are liars.. does it even matter?
Closer to the election and things don't seem to be tipping for McSally

I am confident that Mark Kelly will win the election because he is running as an “ independent” democrat. He is capturing the John McCain spirit of Arizona, whereas Martha Mc Sally has lost all independence from the GOP presidential incumbent. She also lost a senatorial election 2 years ago, and is just not well liked by the people of AZ.  It is possible that McSally could win, but I believe something crazy would have to happen for that to be the outcome.

Mark Kelly has several advantages in this race. His name recognition as an astronaut and spouse of former House of Representative, Gabby Gifford are the obvious ones. Arizona is trending slightly toward "purple" and this could be just enough change to put Kelly in the Senate. A platform based on thoughtful, balanced, common sense approaches to gun control appeals to many in the state. The Republican Party is increasingly being viewed by independents as the party of divisiveness. However, Kelly's lead is estimated to be between 7-9 points. That could narrow in the weeks prior to the election if he does not continue to get his message out to the needed constituents. Therefore, I am giving a 10% chance to Martha McSally.

McSally was appointed to fill McCain’s seat after previously losing a Senate race to a Democrat, so no real benefit of incumbency.  Kelly is well known nationally ( and an astronaut!) and should be able to attract donors.
McSally seems pretty unpopular; however there is already one Democratic Senator, and if the voters want balanced representation, McSally could recover.

The special election is being held in a presidential election year, increasing voter turnout and making it as much about Trump as about the candidates. McSally doesn't have as much name recognition as a normal incumbent due to thr fact she was appointed and never actually won the seat, so any incumbent benefit will be minor if anything. Kelly has wide name recognition due to his NASA time and his wife's background. The state is a "toss-up" by Cook Political Report and given the current situation in the country with Trump at all-time high disapproval ratings, it favors the democratic candidate. Kelly also channels more of the John McCain vibe of being fair and focused on facts and the best decision, not the political party, which will help him take McCain's seat. All 5 major polls taken from March to June also give Kelly the lead by average of 9 points (RealClearPolitics).
Polls have not wavered showing Kelly ahead.
Trump will continue alienating independents and 2016 non-base supporters thru November. Kelly currently has a double digit lead in polls.

In a presidential election year, congressional votes are influenced by voting for a president. With Biden leading in the polls in Arizona that helps lean towards Kelly. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/arizona/ On the actual senate election, there is numerous polls including high quality polling that suggests Kelly already has a firm lead. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/arizona/ Other factors that may not help conservatives: Trump’s response to Coronavirus and rising cases in Arizona in June, a real movement for racial equality and changes that have not been embraced by conservatives.

Kelly and Biden are ahead in the polls. Kelly is an astronaut, giving him status (feels decisive to people). McSally has to overcome Trump impeachment vote.  She might have some pull among gun advocates, but I don’t see that giving her enough of an edge to pull it off.
I'm betting on Rachel Bitecofer's commentary that Ariz will vote D'

Working directly from 538 poll data and making no further assumptions -- just as a starting point.

https://www.nwprogressive.org/weblog/2020/05/scramble-for-the-senate-can-democrats-pick-up-a-seat-in-arizona-with-mark-kelly.html has called it a toss-up. So despite things seeming to go rather well for Kelly, not willing to polarize to much.

Kelly (D) has single digit polling lead and slight fundraising lead. McSally (R) has lost Senate race before but will have incumbent advantage. Cook political report has this as a toss-up and Sabato's Crystal Ball has it lean Dem. My initial estimate is that Kelly wins 3 out of 5 times.

Special election to replace John McCain.  No candidate yet. This seat has been Republican since 1969.  The other senate seat was Republican from 1995 until 2018 when the Democrat won 50 to 47.6. Trump beat Clinton in 2016 Arizona by 48 to 44.5. Latest polling averages have the Democratic candidate winning by 8 points. On Bookies.com, they had the odds of a Democrat at -155 (60.8%) and Republican at 110 (47.6%)

There's a new poll out showing that support for Kelly continues to increase.  Also, there has been some reporting lately about declining support in the 55+ and 65+ age groups for Trump.  There is a larger than average population in Arizona in these age groups.  Less support for Trump probably will weigh down McSally when people show up at the polls.  Also, don't underestimate the goodwill there is in this state for Gabby Giffords, Kelly's wife.
Democrat is leading in the polls now and Trumps presence on the ballot will likely drive high democratic voter turnout.
Kelly leading in polls, has lots of money.  McSally appointed, lost election to Democratic candidate in 2018.
Still a long way to go

Kelly has a poll lead and fundraising lead, but the poll lead is fairly small and in a general election year an increase in partisanship will make it a bit harder for him given Arizona is a mildly red state.

Kelly is out fundraising Marth McSally by a strong margin. However, this seat is held in a presidential year so the Arizona candidates odds closely track with Joe Biden's polls. He is up in Arizona, but Trump won the state last year. We will need to watch the president's approval in Arizona to see the odds of split-ticket voting.
Dems will persuade that current Senate is not meeting the needs of Arizonians.
Fairly red state that may not like the idea of a big blue wave sweeping across government. On the other hand, the hunger for competent governance may be high enough to win the day for Kelly.

A bit of open source research can lead one to suggest this race will be a feeding frenzy that provides job creation for the oppo research "consultants" the type whose birthdays and "seen at" blurbs are glorified by the likes of Politico, and their funny money (subtext "dark") friends who,  through bundlers and their fronts, pay them.  R "consultants" will likely amp up the item that Gwenyth Paltrow is a second cousin to Gabby Giffords according to HuffPost and Showbiz411. But whether the alleged "wierdo" ideas and marketing projects of GP boost McSally's number in this race remains to be seen. Two decorated jet jockeys, one of whom was an astronaut. Neither born in AZ.  McSally grew up in RI, Kelly in NJ with his twin who was also an astronaut. Wild card might be former R Sen. Jeff Flake's statements suggesting R party isn't really behind Trump.  Flake is from an influential LDS family with strong ties across the Southwest.  Republicans who are LDS carry a lot of weight in AZ politics.
Most recent polling suggests trend toward democratic party, however many still appear to be within margin of error.
John Kelly is a strong well-financed candidate and McSally has already lost one Arizona Senate race (albeit narrowly). But if 2018 was any example it will be a really close race.

Mark Kelly leading every poll and McSally is not a true incumbent, having been appointed following the death of John McCain and resignation of John Kyl. However, will voters want two Dem Senators and potentially a Dem President. Many might look to hedge their bets by choosing the Republican.

I think that Mark Kelly is a better candidate than Martha McSally. McSally lost her US representative seat in 2018 to a democratic challenger and is only a senator because she was appointed to the position. Neither she nor Kelly have been elected to the office before so although she has a slight advantage as the incumbent, she also lost her last election to represent Arizona. I think that Kelly will win but I also think that it will be a close election.

I think Mark Kelly checks off all the boxes for a solid candidate as senator in a republican leaning state even though he's a democrat, ex-military, astronaut, name recognition etc. 
The reason i'm giving 65% chance is because we don't know what voting turnout is going to look at in a post covid world so the risk overall is from what kind of a structure we have for voting. Is mail in and remote voting going to be pervasive?
I am giving edge to D. But the R is not weak.
Starting point, expect democrats to strengthen

While I would tend to give the incumbent (R) the advantage, she was appointed to her seat, and the opponent (D) is well known (being married to a former Rep.), has equal military service *and* is a former astronaut.  [1] https://www.electoral-vote.com/evp2020/Senate/Maps/May02.html

Factors favoring Kelly:
1) Fundraising advantage: https://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary?cycle=2020&id=AZS1
2) Expected high unemployment rate by election day Other factors:
1) Uncertainty/election still far away.
2) 2016 election Trump actually did fairly well here compared with other swing states

This race is looking very likely to be between (D) Kelly and (R) McSally (the incumbent). McSally has only been in the senate for a year as she took over from McCain after his death. Arizona is leaning blue and Kelly seems to have a edge in fundraising.

This is one of those races, in a key swing state (albeit one that leans R), that's probably almost perfectly correlated with the presidential election result: in a normal 2020 you'd expect to lean R, in covid 2020, you'd expect it to lean D. I don't see any strong reason to have this probability any significantly different from my forecast for the Presidential election, as of yet, though of course that may change eventually with more polling.
